    <b:includable id='flat' var='data'>
        <ul class='flat'>
          <b:loop values='data:data' var='i'>
            <li class='archivedate'>
              <a expr:href='data:i.url'>
                <data:i.name/>
              </a>
              (
              <data:i.post-count/>
              )
            </li>
          </b:loop>
        </ul>
      </b:includable>
    <b:includable id='interval' var='intervalData'>
        <b:loop values='data:intervalData' var='i'>
          <ul class='hierarchy'>
            <li expr:class='"archivedate " + data:i.expclass'>
              <b:include data='i' name='toggle'/>
              <a class='post-count-link' expr:href='data:i.url'>
                <data:i.name/>
              </a>
              <span class='post-count' dir='ltr'>
                (
                <data:i.post-count/>
                )
              </span>
              <b:if cond='data:i.data'>
                <b:include data='i.data' name='interval'/>
              </b:if>
              <b:if cond='data:i.posts'>
                <b:include data='i.posts' name='posts'/>
              </b:if>
            </li>
          </ul>
        </b:loop>
      </b:includable>
    <b:includable id='menu' var='data'>
        <select expr:id='data:widget.instanceId + "_ArchiveMenu"'>
          <option value=''>
            <data:title/>
          </option>
          <b:loop values='data:data' var='i'>
            <option expr:value='data:i.url'>
              <data:i.name/>
              (
              <data:i.post-count/>
              )
            </option>
          </b:loop>
        </select>
      </b:includable>
    <b:includable id='posts' var='posts'>
        <ul class='posts'>
          <b:loop values='data:posts' var='i'>
            <li>
              <a expr:href='data:i.url'>
                <data:i.title/>
              </a>
            </li>
          </b:loop>
        </ul>
      </b:includable>
    <b:includable id='toggle' var='interval'>
        <b:if cond='data:interval.toggleId'>
          <b:if cond='data:interval.expclass == "expanded"'>
            <a class='toggle' href='javascript:void(0)'>
              <span class='zippy toggle-open'>
                ▼ 
              </span>
            </a>
            <b:else/>
            <a class='toggle' href='javascript:void(0)'>
              <span class='zippy'>
                <b:if cond='data:blog.languageDirection == "rtl"'>
                  ◄ 
                  <b:else/>
                  ► 
                </b:if>
              </span>
            </a>
          </b:if>
        </b:if>
      </b:includable>
  </b:widget>
</b:section-contents><b:section-contents id='footer-1'/></html>

entry.title: Is the Holiday Season a Good Time to List Your Home?
entry.content:
The fourth quarter is a great time to put your home on the market in Tampa Bay because youâ€™ll face less competition and the buyers you encounter will be more serious about buying.

Selling your Tampa home? Get a free home value report
Buying a home? Search all Tampa homes for sale

Itâ€™s been a fantastic year to buy and sell real estate, and weâ€™re now heading into one of my favorite times to put a home on the market. 

Itâ€™s the fourth quarter, and weâ€™re entering the holiday season. A lot of sellers have been taught to believe that itâ€™s a good idea to take their home off the market during the holidays because nothing sells then. 

Well, Iâ€™m here to tell you that nothing could be further from the truth. Tampa Bay is a year-round market with a strong fourth quarter. Would it surprise you to know that last year, a full 25% of the homes that sold in Tampa did so in the fourth quarter? Out of 33,422 home sales across the entire year, 8,831 sales occurred during the fourth quarter. 

If youâ€™re thinking of taking your home off the market and listing it after the new year or once spring comes, have you considered taking advantage of the fact that inventory will be lower now because so many other sellers plan on doing the same thing? Youâ€™ll face less competition, and youâ€™ll deal with fewer but more serious showings because buyers who look for homes during the fourth quarter tend to be more serious. 
Last year, a full 25% of the homes that sold in Tampa did so in the fourth quarter.
Who are these buyers? They include:
  • Out-of-towners flying in over the holidays who want to tie in visits to friends and family with their home-shopping trip.
  • People who are starting new jobs at the first of the year and need a new place to live.
  • In-town residents who want to purchase a home and close on it before December 31st so they can put a put a homestead exemption on it.
  • People who are busy with work and have some time off over the holidays to shop for their homes.
If youâ€™ve been thinking about making a move but have been assuming it would be best to wait until after the holidays to do so, pick up the phone and give me a call so we can go over which options are best for you.

If you have any more questions about our Tampa Bay market, feel free to reach out to me. Iâ€™d love to speak with you.

link.title: Is the Holiday Season a Good Time to List Your Home?

entry.title: Have You Heard of This Amazing Down Payment Assistance Program?
entry.content:
Have you heard of this amazing down payment assistance program that is available in our state? Today Iâ€™m bringing you the details.

Selling your Tampa home? Get a free home value report
Buying a home? Search all Tampa homes for sale
Today Iâ€™d like to tell you about a little known program that has already thousands of people buy homes. This program can give you up to $15,000 toward your down payment. Unfortunately, many of todayâ€™s potential buyers have never heard of this program, so we want to spread the word to all of our friends and clients who might be able to take advantage of this wonderful program before itâ€™s too late!

Back during the housing crisis, the federal government designated funds to help in the bailing out of the housing crisis.

However, because not all of this money was used, the funds that were left over were given to several of the most affected states in order to aid in their recovery.

Florida was one of those states. As a result, state bond money is being given out to aid in home purchases in many counties here in Florida.

Not only does the program give you up to $15,000 toward your home purchase, it also doesnâ€™t need to be repaid as long as you stay in the house for at least five years. 
State bond money is being given out to aid in home purchases.
But this down payment assistance program isnâ€™t going to last foreverâ€”funds for the full $15,000 assistance are running low, and are set to run out around October 31-November 3 this year, and once they do, the program will change. While the program will continue, the amount of money that is offered will be dropping to $7,500, and the repayment requirements are stricter should you sell the home.

So, who qualifies for this program? If you have not owned a home in the last three years, or are a veteran, you may qualify.  Additionally, the income requirements are less strict than you might think. In fact, you can still qualify as an individual with a base salary of up to $82,600.

This program is absolutely worth checking out. If you know anyone who would benefit from this program, please feel free to forward this message on to them, and call us immediately for more details.

If you have any other questions or would like more information, feel free to give me a call or send me an email. We look forward to hearing from you soon.

link.title: Have You Heard of This Amazing Down Payment Assistance Program?

entry.title: Did You Know You Can Appeal Your Property Taxes?
entry.content:
You should have already received in the mail your countyâ€™s assessment of your homeâ€™s value for 2017. Hereâ€™s what to do if you think itâ€™s too high.

Selling your Tampa home? Get a free home value report
Buying a home? Search all Tampa homes for sale

Weâ€™re nearing the end of the summer, which means that your TRIM notice from your county containing the proposed assessed value of your home for tax purposes in 2017 has been sent out.

Itâ€™s not a bill that you have to pay, but it is something that you are going to want to open and read carefully. If you feel that your assessed value is unfairly high, or that you are entitled to an exemption that you have not received, you do have the right to contest it with the county appraiserâ€™s office. However, you only have a short time period in which to do this so acting fast is key. 
We're here to serve as a real estate resource for you.
If you need some advice, give us a call or send us an email and we would be glad to help. Itâ€™s important to know that this assessment may not reflect what your home would sell for today on the open marketâ€”if you need to know what your home would sell for, just call us, and weâ€™re happy to discuss what your home is worth.

If you have questions about how the Property Appraiser determines an assessed value for your home, check out the informative discussions at each of the county websites:

Hillsborough County Property Appraiser website
Pasco County Property Appraiser website
Pinellas County Property Appraiser website

Remember, if you feel your assessment is unfairly high or a mistake has been made, you have the statutory right to appeal it.  Keep in mind that you only have a short time to do so, so don't wait. Here are some helpful links:

How do I appeal my Hillsborough County tax assessment?
Pasco County Real Property Value Appeal Form
How are values determined by the Pinellas County Appraiser?

We also wanted to remind you that our referral rewards contest is still going on. If you know someone who is looking to buy or sell a home in the Tampa Bay area, send them our way and you could win a wonderful vacation on us. Give us a call at 813-907-2555 or email us at Info@TampaHomeGroup.com.

entry.title: 2 Trends to Watch in the Tampa Real Estate Market

Selling your Tampa home? Get a free home value report
Buying a home? Search all Tampa homes for sale
The June numbers just came in. You can check out all of the details here, but there are two important trends that I want to highlight. 

We just had two record-setting months in sales volume and home prices. 

In May, 3,573 homes sold, which is a record for the Tampa market. Then in June, 3,616 homes sold, breaking that record! Overall, there was a 13.2% increase in sales in June 2017 compared to June 2016.

entry.title: How Has Our Market Done This Spring?
entry.content:
Our Tampa Bay market is so hot itâ€™s breaking records. Where is the dividing line between buyers and sellers, though?

Selling your Tampa home? Get a free home value report
Buying a home? Search all Tampa homes for sale


The numbers are in for the month of March, and it was a record-setting one for our Tampa Bay market. Two very important year-over-year statistics prove how well we did compared to March 2016.

First, there were 3,283 closed sales, which was an increase of 22%. To put that into perspective, our market traditionally averages between 2,200 to 2,500 sales per month. Across the market, prices were up roughly 8.7%. Depending on your neighborhood and price range, however, this figure can vary. 
March was a record-setting month for our market.

What do these statistics mean? We have a clear dividing line where we switch from a sellerâ€™s market to a buyerâ€™s market. In Tampa, that dividing line is right around the $500,000 mark. Under that price point, we have less than a six-month supply of inventory. Over that price point, the inventory starts to climb. 

To get a more in-depth look at the latest statistics our spring market has brought, click on this link. 

Who do you know who might need help buying or selling? As a friendly reminder, our Referral Rewards Vacation contest is taking place again this year, and there is still time to refer your friends and family who have real estate needs. Our winner will be drawn in December. If you have any questions about our market, donâ€™t hesitate to give me a call. I would be happy to help you.

link.title: How Has Our Market Done This Spring?

entry.title: Is It Smarter to Remodel Your Home or Just Move?
entry.content:
Should you love it or list it? Depending on your situation, these factors will help you decide if it's smarter to remodel your home or simply move into a new one.

Selling your Tampa home? Get a free home value report
Buying a home? Search all Tampa homes for sale

Should you love your home or list it?

Many homeowners we talk to are thinking about remodeling projects and spending anywhere from $15,000 to $50,000+ on renovations, and wondering if it makes sense to just move to a new home instead. The answer really depends on your own situation, but you certainly want to think about whether the home will support your long-term needs if you make the upgrades, the eventual resale value of your improved home, and whether those improvements will pay off.  There might just be something about your current house that doesn't work for you and your family at this time.  Moving might make more sense, especially if you are over-improving your home for its neighborhood.

Depending on what you decide to do, getting your money out when it comes time to resell can be a challenge, so itâ€™s worth doing a bit of research before you decide.  If you'd like help with this decision, give us a call and we can help you run through the numbers for your individual situation to figure out what's best for you and your family.
Be careful about over-improving for your neighborhood.
If you decide to sell, be aware that the opportunity is good in our market right now, especially if you're selling a smaller home and moving up into a bigger home. That's because the inventory of available houses in the entry-level market and lower price ranges is low, but it's higher in the higher price ranges. You could sell your house at a high-demand level and take advantage of decreased demand and better deals in the higher price ranges. 

You can get a look at all the latest market statistics here.

If you have any questions at all or you'd like to discuss whether it's smarter to renovate your home or move, I'd be more than happy to help. Just give me a call or send me an email today!

link.title: Is It Smarter to Remodel Your Home or Just Move?

entry.title: Why Itâ€™s Crucial to Have a Great Agent on Your Side When Buying New Construction
entry.content:
If youâ€™re buying new construction, do you need an agent? I would highly recommend hiring one for a few reasons.

Selling your Tampa home? Get a free home value report
Buying a home? Search all Tampa homes for sale


Are you focused on a newly built house as your next home?

Many buyers have new construction at the top of their list when they go looking for a home. Thereâ€™s nothing like the feeling of a brand-new, spotless home, that new-home smell, and a blank canvas ready for your own personal touches and preferences to make it your own.

If youâ€™re in the market for new construction, be prepared. There are some common myths, hidden costs, and important things to know when buying new construction, and youâ€™ll want an experienced, professional real estate agent who is not affiliated with the builder on your side to make sure everything goes smoothly. Buying new construction without a buyerâ€™s agent is not unlike going to the doctor without health insurance. In many cases, you arenâ€™t covered or protected, and you will likely end up overpaying.

A builder and the listing agent will give you guidance, but their alliances are to their company, not you. Some buyers mistakenly think they will save on commission when buying new, but the commission is built into the price whether an agent is part of the deal or not. Builders donâ€™t remove that from the price of the home if you donâ€™t use an agentâ€™s services when buying from them. 

A good agent knows that prices are negotiable and will ensure the best deal on the home.
If you donâ€™t have an agent, you may be on your own in more ways than one. Builders often offer greater incentives to agents that agents can then pass along to their buyers. There are often incentives for working with a lender and title company the builder prefers. Many buyers donâ€™t know to ask for closing cost assistance or to have certain premiums waived or reduced.

Your lot selection can be crucial for the future resale of your home, yet not all the home sites that carry premium prices will translate into premium resale value when you go to sell your homeâ€”an experienced agent can advise you on and help you to make the best lot selection, and prevent you from overpaying for a poor lot choice.

Perhaps most importantly, new construction prices are negotiable! Many buyers feel intimidated when visiting a builderâ€™s model center and donâ€™t know they can negotiate on price. Itâ€™s to your advantage to have a buyerâ€™s agent with you â€“ thatâ€™s our job. We ask to negotiate the price and go in armed with our knowledge, skills and experience. We can pull information on comparable homes available locally, and present those to the builder to make the case to get you a lower price and a better value. That may mean asking for closing costs to be reduced, warranties to be extended, better pricing on finishes, or upgrades to flooring, appliances, or window treatments.

As you reach an agreement on price and go under contract, a real estate professional who is knowledgeable about the industry and pricing provides valuable guidance. That can be a huge help when working with the design center to select from your available options and when you consider customizing your home, including structural issues and whether to handle them during construction or outside the building process.

While your home is being built, mistakes can and do happen and the builders need to correct themâ€”this can often be challenging for a buyer going it alone.  No home is perfect, not even new construction, and the issues we see are often crucial to the future enjoyment of your home.

Finally, as your buyerâ€™s agent, we attend the final walk-through with you to help you identify any issues or areas of concern. A professional real estate eye will often see things a person outside of the industry might not notice. Ideally, there wonâ€™t be any problems â€“ at least, any major problems; but there almost always are issues to address, and we have the expertise to work with the builder as your advocate and get any items of concern corrected.

One more noteâ€¦ One of the costliest mistakes we see is when buyers decide to purchase a new construction home, banking on receiving a certain price for their existing home, without ever getting a professional opinion from an experienced listing agent on what their home will really sell for in todayâ€™s market. Itâ€™s easy to get a sense of confidence looking at your â€œZestimateâ€, or prices of current homes on the market in the neighborhood.  The buyer might find out down the road that their house isnâ€™t worth as much as they thoughtâ€”this can result in having to cancel a purchase, or even losing thousands of dollars in deposit money. Just be sure to consult with an experienced agent who successfully sells homes in your price rangeâ€”not a brand new or part time agent.

BEST of all our services of a knowledgeable, experienced buyerâ€™s agent are FREE.

Click here to download my free guide: Why Itâ€™s Crucial to Have a Great Agent on Your Side When Buying New Construction

link.title: Why Itâ€™s Crucial to Have a Great Agent on Your Side When Buying New Construction

entry.title: Why Millennials Should Be Buying Homes Now
entry.content:
Not buying a home is the biggest mistake millennials are making. Hereâ€™s why.

Selling your Tampa home? Get a free home value report
Buying a home? Search all Tampa homes for sale

Do you know a millennial that should be buying a home? Perhaps you yourself are a millennial who is hesitant to make the transition from renter to first-time home buyer. 

Last week, CNBC ran an article quoting self-made millionaire David Bach explaining that not purchasing a home is â€œthe single biggest mistake millennials are makingâ€ because buying real estate is â€œan escalator to wealth.â€

Bach went on to explain:

â€œIf millennials donâ€™t buy a home, their chances of actually having any wealth in this country are little to none. The average homeowner to this day is 38 times wealthier than a renter.â€

In his bestselling book, The Automatic Millionaire, Bach does the math:

â€œAs a renter, you can easily spend $500,000 or more on rent over the years ($1,500 a month for 30 years comes to $540,000), and in the end wind up just where you started â€” owning nothing. Or you can buy a house and spend the same amount paying down a mortgage, and in the end wind up owning your own home free and clear!â€
The average homeowner to this day is 38 times wealthier than a renter.
If you or anyone you know should be buying a home and taking advantage of these historically low interest rates, please reach out to us. We have resources for first-time home buyers, a terrific team of lenders, and all sorts of different programs and people who can assist you in your first home purchase. We even have down payment assistance programs, so there is no need to worry about not having enough to put down. 

If you have any other questions about buying your first home or if we can help you in any way, give us a call or send us an email. We look forward to hearing from you!

link.title: Why Millennials Should Be Buying Homes Now

entry.title: 2016 Market Wrap Up & 2017 Predictions
entry.content:
Our Tampa Bay real estate market is ending on a strong note, and a recent interest rate hike has gotten the attention of the buying public.

Selling your Tampa home? Get a free home value report
Buying a home? Search all Tampa homes for sale

By now, we are all aware that at its December 14th meeting, the Federal Reserve increased its key interest rate by 0.25%. This was the first interest rate hike all year, and only the second interest rate hike in a decade, with the last one being in December 2015. Three more interest rate hikes are forecasted for 2017.

Buyers are now feeling the urgency to purchase and take advantage of low rates. If you have been waiting to refinance, now is also the time to do so if you still have a higher rate, or an adjustable rate. While no one has a crystal ball, the historically low interest rates we have been enjoying might become a thing of the past. 

If you have been thinking of selling your current home and buying another, or buying a home for the first time instead of renting, this is the time to put those plans on the front burner rather than putting it off until the spring or summer. 
Now is the time to buy a home or refinance to lock in a low rate.
On a positive note, November 2016 home sales were up over October 2016 home sales. Typically, November home sales in the Tampa Bay area trail just a little bit behind October home sales. While October 2016 trailed behind October 2015 sales, November 2016 sales rebounded, and were up 20% over November 2015 sales.

We might chalk this phenomenon up to the uncertainty preceding the election, and the increase in sales in November reflected buyers finally feeling confident to move forward.

We want to wish you a merry Christmas, happy Hanukkah, and a blessed and prosperous New Year. 

If you have any real estate questions, please donâ€™t hesitate to reach out to us. We are happy to help.

link.title: 2016 Market Wrap Up & 2017 Predictions

entry.title: Might the Holidays be the Perfect Time to List your Home?
entry.content:
Why list your home during the holidays? Here are three reasons why it may be a better time to list than youâ€™d think. 

Selling your Tampa home? Get a free home value report
Buying a home? Search all Tampa homes for sale

With Thanksgiving just around the corner and the end of the year fast approaching, I just wanted to share with you a conversation I have dozens of times a weekâ€¦should I wait until after the holidays to list my home?

While some people may be under the misconception that the holidays are a bad time to sell, Iâ€™d like to give you three reasons why the holidays are actually one of the best times to list your home:
  1. The Tampa Market is very active in November and December. While the number of actual showings might be fewer, the buyers this time of year are serious. Whether itâ€™s people visiting the area for the holidays looking to buy and only a few days to decide, in-town buyers who have the time off work to shop for homes, buyers that need to close on a home before the end of the year so that they can claim a homestead exemption, or buyers moving here to start new jobs in January, you can rest assured that the people who are out home-shopping now arenâ€™t just tire-kickers.
    2. Home buyers are more serious during the holidays. We all have better things to do.
  2. You will face less competition during the holidays. Because so many sellers take their homes off the market during the holidays, you will have fewer homes on the market to compete with if you choose to list now. Once we hit the first of the year, there will be a flood of new inventory that hits the market.
  3. We can restrict showings for you during the holidays. If you have company coming in or out of your house during certain days, we will have no problem working around your schedule. We can also postpone a closing to keep you in your home until after the holidays if need be as well.
We are working throughout the holidays, so if capturing the holiday market is something you think you may be interested in, or you have any other questions, Iâ€™d love to hear from you. Call or email. We'd be happy to help you!

entry.title: How Can You Increase Your Tampa Homeâ€™s Value?
entry.content:
If you are interested in adding value to your home before you put it on the market, here is a quick list of upgrades and repairs you can make.

Selling your Tampa home? Get a free home value report
Buying a home? Search all Tampa homes for sale

What can you do to increase the value of your home? I have a few quick tips for homeowners who are either looking to increase the resale value of their homes or simply want to maintain their homeâ€™s value.

First of all, you need to maintain your home. Stay on top of small things like exterior paint, servicing your air conditioner, cleaning your gutters, and making sure your pool is in working order. Stay on top of all the little things that might break down in your house. Remember, if you have deferred maintenance items, they will need to be addressed when you sell your home; you will save time and money by repairing things as needed while youâ€™re living in the home.

You should also create curb appeal. A healthy lawn with trimmed trees, bushes, and shrubs will draw the buyerâ€™s eye. You should also add some nice landscaping and pots of colorful flowers to make your home more attractive and approachable to a buyer.

Make sure that the inside of your home is painted in neutral colors. Todayâ€™s buyers are looking for move in ready homes, and the todayâ€™s palette is leaning toward the lighter neutralsâ€”shades of beige and gray that lighten the room; if your home features bold, bright, or dark colors throughout the house, with different colors in every room, buyers will have a hard time picturing their own furnishings in the home. Just because the lime green wall works with your furniture and decor does not mean it will appeal to the next buyer.

On that note, you should also keep your trim well-painted. A fresh coat of white paint on your baseboards, trim, and doors is one of the most economical ways of making your home feel new again.
Modern, updated kitchens sell homes.
Now, replacing outdated flooring is a bigger expense, but doing so can make your home very attractive to todayâ€™s buyers. If you have 12-inch tile from the year 2000 or 8-inch tile from the â€˜90s, you should consider updating your flooring with something that appeals to todayâ€™s buyers. Consider wood plank tiles, hardwood floors, or new carpeting.  Many buyers are limited in the budgets for major projectsâ€”so the fewer major projects they face, the more likely they are to choose your home versus the competition.

As for major renovations, the first room you should look at is the kitchen. Modern, updated kitchens sell homes. The next room you should focus on is the master bathroom.  Todayâ€™s buyers are looking for master bathrooms with a spa-like feel, so luxury showers, and modern sleek finishes have great appeal.

If your budget doesnâ€™t allow for a complete renovation, consider simply replacing counters and installing a modern backsplash. Getting rid of old kitchen appliances and replacing them with sleek modern appliances (in stainless or platinum finishes) will also make your kitchen much more alluring to todayâ€™s buyers.

Finally, one low cost thing you can do to make your entire home feel like new is update your faucets, light fixtures, ceiling fans, or cabinetry hardware. If you havenâ€™t updated these in a while, your home may look outdated. Changing out your cabinetry hardware or light fixtures is a great, inexpensive way to modernize your home.

If you have any other questions about getting your home ready for the market or about our real estate market in general, give me a call or send me an email. I would be happy to help you!

link.title: How Can You Increase Your Tampa Homeâ€™s Value?

entry.title: 4th Quarter Tampa Bay Market Update
entry.content:
As we head into the final quarter of 2016, I have a quick update on whatâ€™s happening in the Tampa real estate market.

Selling your Tampa home? Get a free home value report
Buying a home? Search all Tampa homes for sale

Three quarters of 2016 are behind us and we are heading into the fourth quarter, my favorite time of year. As we head into the final stretch of 2016, itâ€™s time for a Tampa Bay real estate market update.

Year to date, home sales are up by 2.5% compared to 2015. In August, we actually saw a 10% increase in home sales compared to August of 2015. This year, 3,120 homes closed in the month of August while last year August saw 2,827 closings.

The average sales price is up 10% as well. This August, the average sales price was $250,000; in August 2015, the average sales price was $226,000. To put that in perspective, the peak sales price was $286,000 in 2006. Although we are still a long way from reaching that peak, the Tampa market has seen a very strong, healthy gain since 2011.

So what do all of these numbers mean as we head into the fourth quarter? One interesting thing about our current market is that inventory is incredibly low in the entry level and mid level price ranges...in fact, the $300,000 and under market is seeing a significant shortage of homes. However, as we go up in price, the inventory levels grow. Homes priced over $500,000 are in a buyerâ€™s market, and the luxury market (homes priced over $1 million) has 14 months of inventory, which is a huge difference compared to lower price points.
The fourth quarter is still a great time to sell a home.
For those looking to move up, this presents a unique opportunity to sell your current lower priced home in a sellerâ€™s market and move up into a buyerâ€™s market for your next home.

The fourth quarter is a great selling season. A lot of people mistakenly believe that they need to take a home off the market and take a break during the holidays. However, here in Tampa, 7,486 homes sold in the fourth quarter of 2015. That is a full 24% of homes sold in 2015.

This is the time of year when inventory drops because many sellers take their homes off the market. However, that creates a great opportunity for home sellers to list their property and face less competition. There are a few more reasons why the fall and holiday season is a great time to sell your home...more on that in future blogs!

If you have any questions about our current market or about selling your home this fall, give me a call or send me an email. I would be happy to help you!

entry.title: What You Need to Know About â€œAs-Isâ€ Home Purchases
entry.content:
When buyers look to purchase bank-owned homes, most of them are sold â€œas-is.â€ Hereâ€™s what you need to know about that kind of property.

Selling your Tampa home? Get a free home value report
Buying a home? Search all Tampa homes for sale

We have been getting some great questions lately from our clients and weâ€™re going to answer one of them today. This one is about â€œas-isâ€ real estate contracts and bank-owned homes. Here is the question:

â€œMany buyers are looking to purchase a bank-owned home and see the words 'as-is' in the contract. What does 'as-is' mean to a bank vs. a buyer? A buyer might think that the home has to be in a livable condition regardless of whether the contract says 'as-is.' What are your thoughts?â€

When bank-owned properties are put on the market, the bank is making no representation as to the condition of the home. They have never lived in it, so they simply have no way of knowing. As a buyer, it is your responsibility to do any and all inspections necessary to determine the homeâ€™s condition. Per the contract, the bank is not obligated to make any repairs. Some homes might be in such poor condition that obtaining a loan will be impossible, or the cost of the needed repairs and updates might not make sense given the price of the homeâ€”this is when the help of an experienced Buyerâ€™s Agent is invaluable in determining whether it makes sense to place an offer in the first place, and how much to offer.
The bank is not obligated to make any repairs.
When you enter into a contract, you want to be 100% comfortable with having to assume the cost of any repairs or updates that the home is going to need. If something major is uncovered in an inspection, it might be possible to negotiate a repair or a credit depending on the strength of your agent, and the policy of that particular bank, and the inclination of that asset manager. However, you shouldnâ€™t assume that will always be possible. The bank is simply under no obligation to make fixes.

If you have any questions for us, donâ€™t hesitate to give us a call or send us an email. We would love to hear from you.

link.title: What You Need to Know About â€œAs-Isâ€ Home Purchases

entry.title: How to Win in a Multiple Offer Situation
entry.content:
Get FREE instant access to local homes from
any cell or tablet by downloading our KW app!

Whether itâ€™s a buyers or sellerâ€™s market, if the home you love is priced well, you just might find yourself in a multiple offer situation. Here are the top ways to win your dream home:

1. Try not to get in a multiple offer situation in the first place. When you go out to look at homes, make sure you are prepared to make a decision. Make sure everyone who needs to see the home is present at the first showing. Make sure you have an up-to-date pre-approval. If you love the home, donâ€™t wait a couple days to make an offer. That simply opens the door for another offer to come in.

2. Do some homework on the sellers. Have your agent talk to the other agent. Find out whatâ€™s important to the seller. Are there issues other than price that might be important to them? Are they trying to meet a timeframe around the school year or a new job? Tailor your offer to best suit the sellerâ€™s needs.

3. Offer the right price. If a home is priced correctly, you need to offer close to asking price. You may even need to match asking price or go over. Your agent will help you figure out the best price to offer.

4. Put down a strong deposit. We have seen many offers come in with weak deposits of $500, $1,000, or $2,000, sometimes on a 300k, 400k, or 500k home. In this area of the state of Florida, deposits customarily need to be 1.5% or 2% of the purchase price in order for the offer to appear strong and serious.


â€œ
Make sure you put your best foot forward and offer the right price.

â€


5. Donâ€™t ask for closing costs. This weakens your offer and could prevent the seller from choosing your offer.

6. Write a non-contingent offer. Ideally, your offer is not contingent on the sale of your home. If you have to write a contingent offer, though, your home should already be listed, under contract, and through the inspection period so you know your sale is moving forward.  Your agent should communicate all of this to the seller, and include your existing home sale contract with your offer.

7. Tighten up the inspection period. The default inspection period in most contracts is 15 days. Why not make it 7 or 10 days? If you can, shorten that inspection period to 5 days. In a competing offer situation, shorter inspection periods are more attractive to the sellers.

8. Have a strong pre-approval letter. Pre-approvals are different than pre-qualifications. A strong pre-approval letter states that your income, assets, and credit have been verified by the lender. You should also make sure you are working with a good, local lender that the sellerâ€™s agent will recognize, not an out-of-state lender.

If you have any questions, please donâ€™t hesitate to give us a call or send us an email. We would be happy to help you!

entry.title: Why You Need to Avoid Overpricing Your Tampa Home
entry.content:
Get FREE instant access to local homes from
any cell or tablet by downloading our KW app!

Pricing is one of the most crucial aspects of real estate today. Sellers sometimes come to us wanting to list their home at a high price, hoping that someone will make an offer that they can then negotiate on, or that they can come down in price later. There are many reasons to avoid overpricing your home when you list it for sale, and three main reasons stand out as the most important.
Firstly, overpriced listings scare off buyers and agents. Most buyers and agents assume that if sellers were willing to take less, they simply wouldâ€™ve priced their home lower in the first place, and they donâ€™t bother looking at the home at all, or if they do look, they shy away from writing an offer.
Secondly, studies show that homes that are overpriced take significantly longer to sell. We all know that the most impact your home will have is as a brand new listing in those first few weeks on the market. That is when youâ€™ll receive the most attention from buyers and agents. If you spend those first few weeks at the wrong price, you may miss the serious buyers that have been waiting for a home like yours.


â€œ
Buyers online search with a budget. Price your home too high, and buyers wonâ€™t see it.

â€


Finally, if you overprice your home, it will simply be dropped from many of the online searches.  Because buyers have to search with a budget - they cap their online searches at a certain price range. According to the National Association of Realtors, 80% of buyers in 2015 found the home that they ultimately bought online. Pricing a home at market value rather than above will expose your home to the maximum number of qualified buyers.

If you have any questions about pricing your home currently, or youâ€™re just thinking about buying or selling in the Tampa Bay area, give us a call! Weâ€™re always happy to help you, and we look forward to hearing from you.

link.title: Why You Need to Avoid Overpricing Your Tampa Home

entry.title: How Do You Know If Your Zestimate Is Correct?
entry.content:
Get FREE instant access to local homes from
any cell or tablet by downloading our KW app!

Zillow is one of todayâ€™s most popular online home valuation toolsâ€”the â€œZestimateâ€ is their estimation of your homeâ€™s value.  How do you know if your Zestimate is correct? Unfortunately, it probably isnâ€™t. 

I want to warn you all against relying on Zillow to make any real estate decisions, regardless of whether you are buying or selling a home. Consumers these days are increasingly relying on online home valuations, yet these online home estimates are just thatâ€”ESTIMATES. Thereâ€™s no better illustration of that than an article (click here to check it out yourself) that you might have missed in the news back in February about the CEO of Zillow, whose home ended up selling for a whopping 40% less than what his Zestimate!

While Zillow can be a great real estate resource, there are few caveats. First, know that there are certain factors Zillow cannot take into account, such as an irregular lot size, patterns of buyer demand, improvements that might affect your value or unique circumstances surrounding past sales. Zillow does not derive its data from the MLS like professional real estate agents do. The MLS is the most accurate and complete source for listings. On the other hand, professional agents study the market, research the relevant sales, and have often personally been inside the competing homes, and homes recently sold. Thatâ€™s the kind of knowledge you really need to determine your homeâ€™s value.


â€œ
Zillow doesnâ€™t have access to data from the MLS, cannot know about home improvements youâ€™ve made, and does not take into account certain factors about your location and buyer demand.

â€


Zillow even admits that their median error nationwide is 7.9%. What does that mean to you? It means half of Zillowâ€™s Zestimates are off by more than that! You deserve better.

Luxury homeowners beware, Zestimates are even more likely to be inaccurate with high end luxury homes with unique features. 

We are here to help you. If you have any questions about your homeâ€™s value or want to know about improvements that will add value to your home, give us a call. We would be happy to help you!

entry.content:

any cell or tablet by downloading our KW app!

You only get one chance to make a first impression. Did you know 90-95% of buyers begin their home search online? That means the photos your agent posts of your home make that first impression! Photos help a buyer determine whether or not they want to see your home in person, so make sure you take professional photographs. Make your property shine! This is your chance to separate yourself from your competition.

There have been many times where a home sits on the market, and we can point to the photos as the reason. Dark photographs, grainy photographs, and photos that are too small deter buyers. Ensure your agent invests in a professional photographer.


Professional photographers shoot in high definition, so these photos are made to be viewed on a computer screen. Professional pictures will be crisp, clear, well-lit, and the colors will look great on a computer screen. 

Drone photography is perfect to showcase your property, especially if your home sits on a lakefront or a beautiful golf course. Drones can capture lovely panoramic views of your home.

entry.title: Four Ways to Add Value to Your Tampa Home Before a Sale
entry.content:
Get FREE instant access to local homes from
any cell or tablet by downloading our KW app!

One of the most common questions weâ€™re asked is â€œwhat do I need to do to get my home ready to go on the market?â€ Did you know that there are many low cost, high impact ways to improve the sale price of your home without undertaking a major remodeling project? Today I'm going to show you a few inexpensive ways to improve your home before selling.

  1. Curb appeal is incredibly important. Plant some flowers, trim your bushes and palms, pressure wash your driveway, walkways, fences, and decks, add fresh mulch, and a fresh coat of paint on your front door. Make sure the hardware on your front door is shiny and operating well. You only get one chance at a first impression, so don't cut corners here.
  2. As a buyer enters your home, you want them to see a clean and uncluttered property. Remove excess family photos, keepsake items, and excess furniture that take away from the essence of your home. Clearing off counter space is important. Imagine you are in a model home and try to replicate that feel. Stow small appliances, cosmetics, cleaning products, and piles of paperwork out of sight.
  3. Neutralize any dark or bright paint colors. While deep dark burgundy might have looked great with your dÃ©cor, and you might have enjoyed that navy blue accent wall, chances are slim those colors will appeal to the next buyer. Create a positive impression for buyers, who will appreciate that they can move right in. Neutral earth tones work well. Don't forget about your trim and your baseboards! Scuffed baseboards, doors with smudgemarks, and trim that needs touching up creates a â€œtiredâ€ feelingâ€”painting your trim and baseboards goes a long way to making your home feel like new.
  4. Replace dated light fixtures and faucet fixtures. It's amazing how the atmosphere of any room can be altered with updated fixtures. If you still have the original builder grade or outdated light and faucet fixtures, and your home is screaming 1995, a trip to the home improvement store can yield big results. Updating your fixtures is a relatively low cost way of modernizing a room without a huge investment, and it can drastically improve how buyers feel about your home.
There are some other easy things you can do to make your Tampa home stand out on the market.  Part of the service we offer to our valued clients is to suggest the changes that will yield the best return on your investment.

If you want to sell your home this spring, then now is the time to contact us. We look forward to hearing from you!

entry.title: What's the Truth About Selling in the Fourth Quarter?
entry.content:
Get FREE instant access to local homes from
any cell or tablet by downloading our KW app!

Are you waiting until after the holidays to sell your home? We've learned a lot from selling hundreds and hundreds of homes over the years. For some reason, we often see people waiting until spring to sell or even taking their home off the market once the fourth quarter begins, thinking it's best to sell after the holidays. It turns out that this behavior is due to a misconception of how the market works.


The truth is, when we study the data, the fourth quarter has been perennially strong in Tampa Bay year after year, with 25.6% of the homes sales in Tampa last year closed in the fourth quarter! That's a total of over 7,000 homes selling over supposedly slow time in our market. There are three great reasons you should consider being on the market now:

1. Inventory is low: Since many people take their homes off the market during the holidays, you will have a whole lot less competition.

2. Buyers are serious:  We generally find that you'll have fewer showings over the holiday season, yet the buyers who are out shopping are very serious.  There are buyers who want to close by year end for tax reasons, others need a home as they relocate to start a new job in 2016, not to mention the tourists, family, and friends who travel here over the holidays--many are serious homebuyers.  Finally, consider local residents with busy work schedules whose vacation time over the holidays is their only time to shop for a home.  

3. We'll work around your schedule: If you're wondering about how this will work with your holiday company or special plans, we can always block off special times and days that we won't have showings so you can enjoy your plans.  Buyers are understanding this time of year.  We can schedule closing dates to accommodate your schedule, after your holiday plans are completed.

If you have any questions about taking advantage of the 2015 Fall & Holiday Selling Season, or putting your home on the market, or if you would like real estate assistance of any kind, please feel free to reach out to us. We would love to hear from you!

link.title: What's the Truth About Selling in the Fourth Quarter?

entry.title: How to Avoid Overpaying on Property Taxes
entry.content:
Get FREE instant access to local homes from
any cell or tablet by downloading our KW app!

Do you feel like your property taxes are just too high? Do you know how your property tax value is calculated?  Is the value on your proposed tax notice actually what your home is worth?

You should have recently received your notice of proposed property taxes. This in NOT your actual property tax bill, so donâ€™t pay it. It is commonly called a TRIM notice (which stands for Truth in Millage). Naturally, the first thing we all want to see is the Just Market Value of our home.  How is this calulcated? The property appraiser looks at the value of all homes as of January 1, 2015, using past comparable sales from the previous 3-6 months. We generally find that the just market value assigned by the appraiser can vary substantially from your home's true market value.


If you really want to know the value of your home for the purpose of refinancing, or if you are thinking of entering the market,  contact us before you make any big decisions.   As professional agents who study homes and prices every day, we would be happy to help determine a more accurate home value so you can make the best business decision possible.

Your Notice of Proposed Taxes will also provide you with the Assessed Value. This is the Just Market Value of your home minus any assessment reduction. In Florida, the amount that the assessed value can increase is actually capped because of the 'Save Our Homes' Act. This means that the assessed value of homesteaded property can only increase by a maximum of 3% each year.

When your Just Market Value is higher than your Assessed Value, you have Tax Equity. Because we've experienced an improved market in the last few years, a lot of homeowners in our area have Tax Equity. The great thing about tax equity is that it's portable. You can sell your current home and transport that tax equity into your new home, thus preserving the benefits of your tax savings.

Just in case you have the feeling that your taxes are too high, you do have the right to protest them, but time in limited, so act immediately by contacting the property appraiserâ€™s office.  Donâ€™t hesitate to call us if you have questions.

link.title: How to Avoid Overpaying on Property Taxes

entry.title: Three Questions to Ask Your Insurance Agent
entry.content:
Today Chris Black from Chris Black Insurance, one of our preferred agents, joins us to educate us on three key questions we need to be asking our insurance agent to make sure we are truly protected.   Your home is a valuable investment, and you want to be sure you are really covered when you need it, and that you are going to receive the service you need should a claim arise.

Are you with a stable company that provides a quality service? In Florida, we have an intricate insurance market with lots of smaller companies, so you need to do some research to ensure that a company is stable and will be able to pay out its claims.  Chris Black Insurance personally researches all the companies they representâ€”know who is providing your insurance, and how the company is rated.

Who will be handling my claim if I have one? Does my company have its own claims adjusters? Many of the smaller companies that serve the Florida market do not have the proper infrastructure to have their own claims adjusters working for you day-in and day-out. You should be looking for a company that can provide you with an adjuster that actually comes to your house and has the authority to cut a check. You really do not want to settle for anything less!

Which of the coverages that I might need are limited or excluded from my policy? It is crucial for you to know the intricacies of your insurance contract because each one is a little different. You may be covered completely for some things, and you may find that you have limited coverage in other areas. However, it's even more important that your agent understands your contract and can also explain it to you because that is the key to them providing you with an excellent service. You need to know what is covered and what is not.  Key areas where this comes into play are WATER DAMAGE, ANIMAL LIABILITY, and DAMAGE TO SCREEN ENCLOSURES.  Have your agent explain to you exactly what your policy covers before the unforeseen happens and you discover you were not covered the way you thought you were.

Hopefully these questions have been useful to you. If you have any other questions about your policy, please be sure to contact Chris at (877) 807-1333, he is always willing to speak with you.

As always, if you need any assistance when you're buying or selling in Tampa, please do not hesitate to contact me!

link.title: Three Questions to Ask Your Insurance Agent

entry.title: How to Buy and Sell Simultaneously
entry.content:
Thank YOU to our valued clients, friends and the community for making us the top selling Keller Williams Team in the entire North Florida Region!
 
Today we'll be discussing three strategies that you can utilize if you've sold your home and are looking to buy another one.
  1. Purchase New Home Before Selling: If your finances are in order, you may be able to purchase a home before selling your own, but you run the risk of paying two mortgages at one time. One possible way around this sticky situation is to utilize the home as a rental property.
  2. List and Sell Before Purchasing: If paying two mortgages is not an option for you, then this is your best bet. We can certainly help to arrange interim housing, or we'd be glad to help write up contingencies on your home offers so that you are not moving in between homes during this process.
  3. Simultaneously Sell and Purchase: We specialize in these types of transactions, and they aren't as imposing as they may seem. It takes a little bit of planning and organization, but we do this for many of our clients.
You'll want to speak with us about how much money you can expect to get out of your Tampa home sale before you start planning your move. Knowing an accurate time frame for how long it will take your home to sell is another important part of this process, because time is of the essence when you're trying to buy and sell at the same time.

We're always here to help, so please don't hesitate to contact us. Consider us your #1 resource for real estate in Tampa!

entry.title: Is Zillow Accurate?
entry.content:
Thank YOU to our valued clients, friends and the community for making us the top selling Keller Williams Team in the entire North Florida Region!
 

Thank YOU to our valued clients, friends and the community for making us the top selling Keller Williams Team in the entire North Florida Region!

Just how accurate are the online home valuations? The truth might shock you. The website that sellers ask us about most often is Zillow, so we did some research to see just how accurate they are. You may be surprised to find out that in Tampa Bay the median error of their Zestimates (the number on your roof when you type in your address) is 8.8%.  

By their own admission, only 31% of their Tampa area Zestimates fall within 5% of the actual home sale price, and over 20% of Zestimates are off by over 20%! 

When it comes to the value of your home, there is simply no substitute for the experience and advice of a savvy professional agent.  

Over the past five years, our track record in predicting a homeâ€™s value has been accurate within 0.5%!  So when it comes to making important real estate decisions, donâ€™t depend on an automated algorithm to help you make your most crucial decisions.  

Can you afford to be off by as much as 20% or more?

Zillowâ€™s own data reports the actual difference between Zestimate predictions and actual sale prices.
  • Zillowâ€™s Report Card in Tampa: Median Error in Tampa, FL is 8.8% (http://www.zillow.com/zestimate/#acc) 
  • John & Mariaâ€™s Report Card: Accuracy within  0.5% (MLS data complied listings sold, Sale Price vs. List Price 2/16/2010 through 2/16/2015)
 
Maybe you donâ€™t need to sell right now, but youâ€™d like to know what homes are actually selling for in your neighborhood without your information being sold to third parties. We have an in-house resource that deals specifically with your neighborhood and focuses the information on your specific home, taking data directly out of the Multiple Listing Service, unlike Zillow, Trulia, and many others, which rely on tax records and sales figures compiled from other sources. entry.title: Why is Now the Time to Make Your Move in Tampa?
entry.content:
There are many great Tampa area homes for sale. Click here to perform a full home search, or if you're thinking of selling your home, click here for a FREE Home Price Evaluation so you know what buyers will pay for your home in today's market. You may also call us at (813) 907-2555 for a FREE home buying or selling consultation to answer any of your real estate questions.

Today we are joined by one of our preferred lenders, Ken Ynes of NFM Lending. Current mortgage opportunities include many low down payment programs, lowered mortgage insurance rates, and refinancing to lower your monthly payment or overall term of your loan.  Which of these opportunities might be right for you?

Over the past few months, rates have been extremely low, as low as they have been in several years.  Low rates are good news for buyers and sellers. Buyers are able to lock in low rates, and sellers take advantage of the fact that low rates bring many more buyers to the market. 

In addition to low interest rates, there are also plenty of great downpayment options when purchasing a home. If you are looking to move up into a newer or larger home, NFM lending is currently offering a 5% down loan on a $658,000 purchase. Only 5 years ago, the down payment on this loan amount would likely have been at least 20% !

For smaller loans, there are options with even lower down payments.  FHA loans still offer  a 3.5% downpayment.   Additionally, FHA has recently lowered the annual mortgage insurance premium from 1.35% to .85%, which lowers the monthly payment for borrowers.  There are also new conventional loan programs that will let you borrow with as little as 3% down, as an alternative to FHA financing.

Mortgage insurance is a fee that is charged to anyone who doesn't put 20% down. Basically, it insures the money in the event of a default.  NFM Lending, located right here in Tampa, offers a Lender Paid Mortgage Insurance Program, where the lender actually covers the cost of mortgage insurance and effectively lowers the borrowers' payments. 

Another way to lower your monthly housing payment is through refinancing. Currently, we are able to take a look at purchases from 2010 and either lower the interest rate, possibly remove mortgage insurance, or convert from a 30-year loan to a 15-year fixed rate.

If you would like to take advantage of the many great opportunities out there right now in the lending world, give us a call at 813-907-2555 or send us a quick email mariahoffman@verizon.net.

Happy New Year!

entry.title: Why Are Conditions So Favorable For Sellers?
entry.content:
There are many great Tampa area homes for sale. Click here to perform a full home search, or if you're thinking of selling your home, click here for a FREE Home Price Evaluation so you know what buyers will pay for your home in today's market. You may also call us at (813) 907-2555 for a FREE home buying or selling consultation to answer any of your real estate questions.

A Tampa Real Estate Market Update

Year to date, 2014 has been a strong and healthy year for the Tampa Bay real estate market, and opportunities exist in many segments of the market.  Today we want to examine what the current numbers mean, particularly for those who may be considering selling in the next six to ten months.

It has been a strong, healthy year with about 20,450 homes closing in our market. That is just slightly above last yearâ€™s 20,074. That is an indication that home sales are strong and steady. September to September, the numbers look even better with 2,082 homes closed in September 2013, versus 2,362 closing in September 2014 or about a 15% increase year over year for the month.  As we enter the holiday season, many potential sellers, and sellers whose homes have failed to sell during the year decide to take their homes off the market,

The reality is that there are only currently 9,541 homes on the market. That may seem like a large number, but that is a year-long low in our market. That number was 12,942 in January of this year. Since we know historically about 25% of home sales in our market occur in the fourth quarter, that means listing your home now can actually increase its chances of being sold, and possibly for a higher price than when the inventory increases after January 1.

Consider that over 6,200 homes were sold in the fourth quarter of last year. That means if you list your home right now, your competition is dramatically less, considering that only about 9.500 total homes are on the market. On the other hand, if you wait until after the end of the year, you will be joining thousands of other homeowners who put their homes on the market after the holidays.  In other words, your home will  be in a year-long low pool of 9,500 by listing now  OR you can wait a  few months and it will likely be joined by the many sellers who follow the conventional belief that â€œnothing sells over the holidays.â€  Here in Tampa, there are serious buyers out in November and December who must buy a homeâ€”youâ€™ll find that your number of showings may be slightly decreased, yet the buyers that are looking are serious and motivated.

Getting your home listed is a fairly quick process and we are here to help. If you have been thinking about selling your home, now is a good time to move. Contact us and we can help you make the most of your real estate transaction.


Our Referral Rewards Vacation Getaway is Back!

We are pleased to announce that our Referral Rewards Vacation Getaway returns on Dec. 6th. If youâ€™ve already bought or sold with us this year, youâ€™ll already have a chance to win, AND you can receive additional entries by referral by our drawing date. Our winner gets a trip for two to one of four fabulous vacation destinations.

Our Referral Rewards Vacation Giveaway is one more  way for us to thank those who have referred friends and family to us. We appreciate your referrals and are always looking for special ways to demonstrate our gratitude. Our whole team is committed to make your next real estate transaction the best one youâ€™ve ever had.

link.title: Why Are Conditions So Favorable For Sellers?

entry.title: How to Decide Whether to Rent or Sell your Home
entry.content:
There are many great Tampa area homes for sale. Click here to perform a full home search, or if you're thinking of selling your home, click here for a FREE Home Price Evaluation so you know what buyers will pay for your home in today's market. You may also call us at (813) 907-2555 for a FREE home buying or selling consultation to answer any of your real estate questions.

What Factors Should I Consider Before Becoming a Landlord?

We often are asked if it is wiser to sell a property or rent it out when the seller can't get the desired price for it. The answer depends on the numbers and your long term goals. Let's analyze your actual cash flow taking into account all of the following:

  • Write down all your expenses. This includes your mortgage payment, principal interest, taxes, and insurance. If you have a homesteaded property, keep in mind your taxes go up once it becomes rental property. The homestead exemption will be lifted and the cap that limits annual increases will no longer be 3%.
  • Next, you need to budget for monthly expenses such as homeowner's association dues, lawn mowing, lawn treatment, pool maintenance.
  • You also need to budget for miscellaneous repairs. All homeowners are accustomed to these inevitable monthly repairs, such as for irrigation systems, A/C repairs, pool pumps, roof leaks, hot water heaters, appliance repairs. Make sure to budget for annual HVAC maintenance as well.
  •  If you either aren't comfortable being a landlord, have a hectic work or travel schedule, or live a long distance away and are unable care for the property, you will need to budget for a property management company.
  • Realistically, expect that your home may not have a tenant for at least 1 month of the year, so you'll want to plan on a 1 month vacancy factor.
  • Fast forward one, two, and three years. What are the potential impending large expenses such as replacing A/C units, roof replacement, remarciting the pool, replacing a pool pump, or a major appliance? Losing a tenant and re-renting the property often calls for paint and/or carpet.
  • Finally, keep in mind that the average cost to put a home back into selling condition after it has been tenant occupied ranges from $4,000 to $10,000. Will the future appreciation of the home be enough to offset all of these expenses? Call us to determine the market trends in your area.

With these budgeting tips in mind, you should have a better idea of whether or not renting is the right decision. Even if your home is paid off, you'll want to analyze the opportunity cost of renting your property â€“ are there other investment opportunities that may not involve the risks of being a landlord? That is a question you need to take seriously before going down the rental path. If youâ€™d like some guidance coming up with the best plan for your personal situation, give us a call or send us an email and we can help you determine what works best for you, and we are happy to refer you to excellent rental agents if needed.

Wondering what your home would sell for in todayâ€™s market? Send us an email at mariahoffman@verizon.net or call us at 813-907-2555.

link.title: How to Decide Whether to Rent or Sell your Home

entry.title: Avoid These 3 Common Mistakes When Selling a Home
entry.content:
There are many great Tampa area homes for sale. Click here to perform a full home search, or if you're thinking of selling your home, click here for a FREE Home Price Evaluation so you know what buyers will pay for your home in today's market. You may also call us at (813) 907-2555 for a FREE home buying or selling consultation to answer any of your real estate questions.


As you plan the successful sale of your home, avoid these 3 common mistakes sellers make during the listing and selling process. We are here to help you make smart real estate decisions for you and your family and we want you to be informed on all aspects of home selling. Including the type of service and results you should expect from a professional agent.

1. Treat your home sale as an important business decision
Never pick an agent based out of a sense of obligation to a friend or family member without thoroughly researching the agent and asking a few key questions first. Since past performance is the best predictor of future results, a great agent will be happy to share their track record and contact information for references. We have compiled a list of 19 questions for you to ask your potential agent called "A seller's guide to interviewing an agent to sell your property" and we would be happy to send this out and share it with you. Give me a call at (813) 907-2555 or email me at mariahoffman@verizon.net if you would like a copy.

2. Enter the market at the proper price
Real Estate markets are highly localized and can change on a weekly basis. While many sellers are tempted to enter the market overpriced to leave room for negotiating, studies prove that homes that enter the market substantially overpriced actually end up selling for less in the long run. Supply and demand can effect prices so it is crucial to hire an agent that understands market trends and studies the market intensely on a daily basis. This can be one of the most expensive mistakes a seller can make. Pricing your home accurately with the help of an agent will get you a much better offer and will make your home sale much easier. We have compiled a guide called "Pricing Strategies", a 2-page comprehensive guide to all the factors involved in pricing a home. We would be happy share this tool with you as well.

3. Allow buyers to view the home without you being present
Giving the buyers the space they need in your home allows them to speak freely, feel more comfortable in the home, and allows them to envision themselves living in the home as the owners. Their agent who is aware of the buyers needs will be able to ask them direct questions freely, so as to better be able to sell your home. 

By following these 3 tips, selling your home will be much easier and less worrisome. As always, if you or anyone you know has questions about your own personal real estate situation, give us a call immediately! We would be more than happy to help!

link.title: Avoid These 3 Common Mistakes When Selling a Home

entry.title: Avoid the Pitfalls of Online Home Searches
entry.content:
There are many great Tampa area homes for sale. Click here to perform a full home search, or if you're thinking of selling your home, click here for a FREE Home Price Evaluation so you know what buyers will pay for your home in today's market. You may also call us at (813) 907-2555 for a FREE home buying or selling consultation to answer any of your real estate questions.


Online Web Searches Cannot Take the Place of a Knowledgeable Agent
 
As the role of the internet grows in our daily lives, we take for granted that the information at our fingertips is accurate.  However, when it comes to real estate, donâ€™t assume everything you find online is accurate.  Popular home search websites are the starting point for many real estate searches, yet there are some common pitfalls to avoid that weâ€™ll share in todayâ€™s message.

To prevent wasting energy, time, and money, know this before you invest your time searching online:
  1. The best and most authoritative source for real estate listings is your local Multiple Listing Service (MLS) which is the service that professional agents use to market and sell their listings.  In addition, itâ€™s great to have the inside knowledge of a strong listing agent who personally lists property and is networking with other agents on a daily basis to alert you to homes coming on the market soon. Zillow, Trulia, and many of todayâ€™s popular online real estate sites do not draw their information from the MLS â€“ they instead pull their information from tax records and other sources. This leads to consumers researching homes that may be already sold, under contract, not for sale at all, or missing key details that only a realtor will have access to. There have been countless instances where a buyer has come to our office with a list of homes that they have their heart set on, only to find that those homes have either been sold, are already under contract, or there is a major issue with the home that is contained in the Realtor remarks that the general public cannot see.
  2. Your information is up for sale. The lifeblood of these websites comes from the sale of your personal information to local agents or lenders. When you inquire about one of these homes, you are probably under the impression that you will be communicating with the listing agent. In reality, that website may be sending your inquiry to an agent and/or lender who has purchased rights to that zip code. This puts you into contact with someone that could have zero knowledge of the property, or little experience.

  3. Hire a professional agent. Save yourself the time and frustration of calling around from agent to agent tracking down properties that may or may not be available.  An experienced agent can help you avoid wasting your precious time on scenarios that donâ€™t make sense for you.  For example, there are a number of homes being marketed on websites at below market prices, but in reality these homes are being sold under auction terms and the price is only an opening bid, not what the seller will be willing to take for the home. Donâ€™t be surprised to find small print like extra fees (a buyerâ€™s premium of 5% on top of sale price is common) and often the home is sold with no contingency for inspection. Experienced agents can alert you to these scenarios.
The bottom line is this: if you are serious about starting your home search, hire a professional real estate agent.   Popular websites can occasionally be useful starting points, but using them as your sole base of knowledge most often ends in wasted time and disappointment.

If youâ€™d like to download a great home search app and know that your information will not be sold, then text â€œKWâ€ to 87778,   OR click here to download our custom home search app:  http://app.kw.com/KW2B37JI8

link.title: Avoid the Pitfalls of Online Home Searches

entry.title: Why It will Be Crucial to Price your Home Properly in 2014
entry.content:
Buyers click here to search all area homes for sale.

Sellers click here to find out what your home is worth.

Why It will Be Crucial to Price your Home Properly in 2014


Itâ€™s our constant mission to keep you informed on changes in the Tampa Bay real estate market. This information is part of the research that we conduct daily to bring you the clearest picture of what is going on and what you can expect out of the market if you need to sell or buy. This is all necessary so we can position our clientele to succeed in any real estate market.

Inventory is Rising:
  • In the $350,000-$399,000 range we've seen inventory jump from 278 homes on the market January 2013 to 481 homes on the market January 2014. 
  • In the $500,000-$599,000 range inventory was at 162 homes last January, and is now at 233 this January.
  • In the $1,000,000+ range, inventory has increased from 214 homes last January to 239 homes this January. 
  • From homes priced in the $200,000-$250,000 range, there were 688 available last year, and this year there are now 1,069 available on the market.
What this means for Sellers:
  • Pricing is going to be more important than ever. With more choices available to buyers, including options in new construction, you're going to need to stand out to the buyers with attractive pricing. 
  • Home sales are still strong, fueled by the low interest by low interest rates, and pent up demand. 
  • If you're thinking of listing your property, you need to look at your home through the eyes of a buyer, and compare it with the other options buyers have.
  • Research shows that a home that is priced correctly will sell faster and also for more money than a property that is overpriced. 
  • As we transition into a more balanced market from a seller's market, remember to pay special attention to the condition of your property. Don't forget curb appeal, decluttering, and fixing items that could be considered deferred maintenance. When we list your home, weâ€™ll help you to take the right steps to get it ready to stand out.

If you have any further questions, or if youâ€™re thinking of making a move and want to talk about your options, please call us directly at 813-907-2555
