entry.title: What Can You Expect to See in the Tampa Real Estate Market for 2014?
entry.content:
Buyers click here to search all area homes for sale.

Sellers click here to find out what your home is worth.

What Can You Expect to See in the Tampa Real Estate Market for 2014?

Happy New Year! 2013 was a fantastic year in the Tampa Bay market to both buy and sell real estate. Coming off the heels of 2013, we wanted to give you a home price and mortgage update for 2014. Joining us today are my two colleagues, Jason Hunter of SunTrust Mortgage and Ken Ynes of Diversified Home Mortgage to give us additional insight and news on the changing mortgage market.

While home prices rose about 12-14% last year, we anticipate a more modestly appreciating market (more around 3-5% with the possibility of a flat market in some price ranges depending on interest rates and the stock market). The buying frenzy from the first part of 2013 has tapered off, the hedge funds have pulled back from their massive purchasing and buyers are more cautious about affordability. Inventory is starting to rise and in some price ranges, especially the higher ones, sellers will have to pay close attention to the market and fluctuating interest rates can have an immediate effect on what buyers can afford.

The number of home sales was over 35,000 and we have not seen a number that high since 2005. The rate of â€œunderwater homesâ€ plunged from 45% to 30% and two-thirds of home sales in 2013 were â€œnon-distressed,â€ unlike 2011 where distressed sales (short sales and foreclosures) made up well over half the home sales.

These days, weâ€™re seeing a lot more flexibility in the mortgage market and loan programs. FHA limits have gone down to $271,050.00 beginning January 1, 2014.   This marks a change from previous years when the loan limit was $292,000.  Sellers should be aware of this as it is restricting some buyers' purchasing power, as FHA loans only require 3.5% down. Buyers can access conventional loans with as little as a 5% down payment. Home Equity Lines are making a comeback as sellers in Tampa are regaining equity as home prices are on the rise. Over the last six months, new Home Equity Line applications have increased dramatically with the maximum loan to value amount of 85%. If you have a home improvement project that needs to be finished, this might be a good option.

Buying a new home may cost less than you think, and waiting may cost more than you realize.

Rates are hovering in the mid 4â€™s with most experts expecting they will be rising and will be higher by the end of the year. The window of opportunity still exists for homeowners to sell and move up or downsize.  We predict that this advantageous situation will dictate the real estate market of 2014, which will consist in large part of homeowners selling one home to move up or downsize, as well as â€œaccidentalâ€ landlords deciding to sell because it is possible, and preferable to the costs of continued property maintenance.   New construction is on the rise, and many of our clients have opted to buy/build a new dream home.   Fluctuating rates could affect the market at any time, like last May when the rates jumped up almost a full point, so if you know anyone considering making a move, now would be a great time to meet and look at how we can help you move up to that dream home or downsize.

Thank you joining us today! Remember we are here for all of your real estate needs. Whether itâ€™s the value of your home, refinancing or purchasing a home, donâ€™t hesitate to call us!

link.title: What Can You Expect to See in the Tampa Real Estate Market for 2014?

entry.title: Youâ€™ve Made a Deal, But What is the Next Step?
entry.content:
Youâ€™ve Made a Deal, But What is the Next Step?

Congratulations on our contract for your new home! Iâ€™m here with Tania Borelli, our client care manager, who is going to be helping you from this point forward. At this stage, we want to help you with what you can expect next. I want to make sure you know what you should be doing going forward. We are here every step of the way to get you to the closing table. When you need us, Tania is able to be reached (813) 907-2555; I am typically on the phones until noon every morning finding buyers for my sellers and vice versa so Tania is the person to speak to. She does a fantastic job of keeping you on track!

Below are the tasks we take care of once we receive the executed contract

1.    Deposit. We are responsible for taking your deposit to the title company. Whether itâ€™s been hand delivered, mailed or wired, we are bound by contract to make sure the title company gets it within three days.

2.    Inspections. We have a list of home inspectors that we will gather quotes from and email to you. Once you choose which inspector works for you, let us know and we will make the arrangements with the listing agent to schedule on the date you have chosen. For the home inspection, we will typically be there for the last 30 minutes of the inspection to take pictures, take measurements or show a family member the home as this will most likely be the only time to do so. This is to let the home inspectors do their job as inspections can take anywhere from 3-5 hours. If for whatever reason you canâ€™t make the inspection, we are there to represent you by receiving a full report including pictures.

3.    Choose your lender. You are bound by contract to make a full loan application within five days. If you already have an existing preapproval or relationship with a lender and intend to continue with that particular lender, just let both (the lender and ourselves) know. We will send a copy of the executed contract to your lender.

4.    Home insurance. Along with the list of home inspectors that we will send you, information regarding home insurance will in that as well. Reference that list or if you have an existing relationship, still be sure receive 2-3 quotes and secure your home insurance.
Our main job is to ensure that we all working according to the contract and that everyone is informed! If you need anything, be sure to contact Tania. Thank you and congratulations on your home!

entry.title: 3 Reasons to Sell During the Holidays
entry.content:
3 Reasons to Sell During the Holidays

The holidays are here and that always brings the question whether now is a good time to sell or not. Thereâ€™s a big misconception that the holiday months arenâ€™t a good time to list your home, but that simply isnâ€™t true.

There are actually three great reasons to why LISTING A HOME NOW works to your advantageâ€¦
  1. Here in the Tampa Bay area, a large number of homes sell over the holidays. Historically, December sales have always been healthy, in fact last year here in Tampa, we saw 2,081 sales in December.
  2. Buyers are more serious, so that while you may have fewer showings overall, the buyers out there looking tend to be motivated. Many families relocate to the area for jobs starting in January, others wish to purchase for tax reasons, and donâ€™t forget, many busy professionals have time off over the holidays and actually have time to shop for a home. Snow birds and vacationers are all heading down to Florida this time of year as well.
  3. Best of all, if youâ€™re a seller, competition from other homes is much lower now than it will be after New Yearâ€™s through the spring months, when many homeowners decide to list their homes â€“ so there may be a significant financial advantage to putting your home on the market now versus waiting.
We understand here at Tampa Home Group that your family time is important. We can absolutely restrict showings during times when you have company or special family events, and of course, we can negotiate a closing date between you and the buyers that works for your family. Weâ€™ll make the whole process easy for you.

So whether you are thinking of waiting, or listing now, give us a call and we can explore the options that make the most sense for you! Have a happy holiday season!

entry.title: What is going on with home prices in Tampa, FL?
entry.content:
What is going on with home prices in Tampa, FL?

The first part of the year has been fantastic and now that summer is behind us, we are starting to see the market slow down a bit.  The Tampa Bay market has seen about a 12% increase across the board since the beginning of 2013, this varies depending on your neighborhood, The slowdown, however, stems from a few factors. On May 22nd we had a slight rise in mortgage rates,  rising from the low to mid-3% range to the current mid-4% range.  Despite the slight increase, rates are still historically low and the market will stay healthy while the interest rates remain under 5%.

Weâ€™ve seen the big hedge funds scale back on purchasing properties, they were purchasing hundreds a month, and that has come to a halt.  As the rental market become saturated with the influx of rental property hitting the market, the hedge funds appear to be waiting for the rentals to be absorbed by the market before they start purchasing again.  

Overall we still find our market presents an outstanding opportunity for both buyers and sellers. Check out this terrific article from the September issue of Kiplingerâ€™s Personal Finance Magazine which is titled Cash in on Your Home. It details the window we are in right now in which the upward movement in prices has created a situation in which more homeowners have the equity and the ability to sell compared to a few years ago when this was not the case.   With low interest rates, buyers have the purchasing power to get into a terrific home.  This window wonâ€™t last forever, so thousands of families are taking advantage of the positive changes in the market.

Kiplingerâ€™s states that â€œas of June 30, prices had increased 8.6% nationally from the year before, reports Clear Capital, a provider of real estate analysis and data,â€ and that â€œOn average, home prices have risen 10.8% since the trough in August 2011, but theyâ€™re still well below their peak.â€ In regards to the market swinging in the sellerâ€™s favor, â€œmost marketâ€™s limited supply has given sellers the advantage. The rush to snap up homes and pounce on low mortgage rates has even sparked bidding wars in some areas. For the first time in years, you can expect that if you prepare and price your home right, it will sell quickly and for full price or more.â€

In Tampa, we are still 30% below the home prices of 2006 and over the course of the spring and summer, Tampa Home Group has helped dozens families sell their home and purchase their next. If youâ€™re on the fence about buyer and selling, now is the perfect time to do so and you can always give us a call at (813) 907-2555.

link.title: What is going on with home prices in Tampa, FL?

entry.title: Government Shutdown Risks Hurting The Housing Recovery
entry.content:
Government Shutdown Risks Hurting The Housing Recovery

From: http://www.forbes.com/sites/morganbrennan/2013/10/01/heres-how-the-government-shutdown-will-affect-housing/

By:  Morgan Brennan, Forbes Staff

The government shutdown is here. Whether itâ€™s not being able to get a new Social Security card or visit a national park, Americans will immediately feel the effects. But thereâ€™s one bright spot of the economy that stands to be affected as well: housing.

One of the biggest questions regarding the shutdown and how it will affect housing has revolved around the mortgage market, specifically prospective buyersâ€™ access to new home loans. After all, more than 90% of all loan activity is underwritten, insured, or owned by the government and its affiliated entities.

Initially at least, the mortgage market is likely to be only minimally impacted. New loans will continue to push through most government agency pipelines. What will change is how long the process takes, as many agencies expect to experience delays.

Mortgages purchased and securitized by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac will be unaffected because their operations are paid for by fees charged to lenders. And the Department of Veterans Affairs will continue to guarantee mortgages for Americans that have served in the military since these loans are funded by user fees as well.

But if the government shutdown of 1995-1996 is any indicator, the process will take longer than usual. â€œLoan Guaranty certificates of eligibility and certificates of reasonable value were delayed,â€ the VA warned in its September 25th contingency plan.

Where there has been mounting concern is the Federal Housing Administration, which currently endorses about 15% of the entire single-family mortgage market. Several media outlets recently reported that the FHA would be unable to endorse any single-family loans and that no staff would be available underwrite and approve new loans.

That prospect would be somewhat worrisome â€“ if it were actually true. The FHAâ€™s Office of Single Family Housing will indeed remain open for business, albeit with a smaller staff. â€œFHA will be able to endorse single family loans during the shutdown. A limited number of FHA staff will be available to underwrite and approve new loans,â€ the report now states. In other words, other lendersâ€™ loans will continue to be insured and some in-house lending will continue to take place at a reduced rate.

The reason for that mix-up: the initial draft of the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Developmentâ€™s contingency plan mistakenly stated that single-family loan operations would cease. The report was amended over the weekend.

The FHAâ€™s single-family loan operations are funded through multi-year appropriations, meaning their budget is not tied to the governmentâ€™s standoff over funding for the new fiscal year that starts in October. On the other hand, what will be more affected is the agencyâ€™s Multifamily Housing Office, which is funded through yearly appropriations.

â€œBecause we are able to endorse loans, we donâ€™t expect the impact on the housing market to be significant, as long as the shutdown is brief,â€ continues the HUD report. â€œIf the shutdown lasts and our commitment authority runs out, we do expect that potential homeowners will be impacted, as well as home sellers and the entire housing market.â€

One government lender that will indeed suspend its home loan activity, however, is the Department of Agriculture. The USDA says that no new housing loans or guarantees will be issued through its Rural Development programs in a shutdown. The department also warns that such a scenario could cause â€œa setback in construction start-up,â€ and if the shutdown lasts for an extended period, â€œa substantial reduction in housing available in rural areas relative to population.â€

â€œThe government doesnâ€™t generally approve loans, they basically just insure them,â€ says Don Frommeyer, president of the National Association of Mortgage Brokers and a vice president at Amtrust Mortgage Funding. â€œFor the most part you arenâ€™t going to see much of a hit in the mortgage market unless it goes for a long period of time.â€

If it does stretch on, he adds, the worry will be what mortgage rates do in a market shrouded in fiscal uncertainty and how that will affect the home buying, especially in light of recent rate spikes.

Home lending aside, many economists and real estate experts are keeping a close watch on how Americans will react to this shutdown. â€œAdministratively everything should keep moving along, but itâ€™s more about the confidence of consumers and whether they perceive that the government shutdown could lead to a recession,â€ says Lawrence Yun, chief economist at the National Association of Realtors.

Moodyâ€™s Analytics chief economist Mark Zandi recently told the Senate Budget Committee that a partial shutdown could shave as much as 1.4 percentage points off of fourth quarter economic growth if it drags on for several weeks.

Americansâ€™ confidence in their ability to buy and sell homes hit a record high in May, according to a Fannie Mae survey. Since then, as mortgage rates jumped more than a percentage point, that confidence level has plateaued.  If prospective homebuyers fear that the countryâ€™s economic recovery will stall, or worse slip back into recession, they will pull back on purchases, worries Yun.

â€œHome sales is always the first housing variable that changes so one would see sales declining and that would naturally lead to more inventory on the market and eventually put pressure on prices,â€ he says. But that would be a worst-case scenario based on a long-term shutdown.

Jed Kolko, chief economist at Trulia TRLA +6.43%, notes that if the shutdown lasts longer than a few days, the first places to feel the impact will be local economies with large concentrations of federal government workers. Metro areas like Washington, D.C. and Bethesda, Md., where 19% and 13% respectively of total local wages go to federal employees, would be the feel the negative effects of unpaid furloughs and with them, tightened consumer spending and weakening local economic growth. Though not all will be equally affected, other metro areas like Virginia Beach, Va., Honolulu, Hawaii, and Dayton, Ohio are areas that Kolko is keeping an eye on: â€œWhether there is a big effect depends on how long the shutdown lasts, how long people think the shutdown lasts, and whether people get back-pay. All those things matter for the impact.â€

Still others are worrying even more about the next fiscal standoff, in  mid-October, surrounding the debt ceiling debate and its accompanying threat of debt default by the U.S.  â€With the threat of an impending partial government shutdown and yet another battle over the nationâ€™s debt ceiling, in particular, we are really messing with fire right nowâ€”even if it doesnâ€™t seem to bother some legislators,â€ says Stan Humphries, chief economist at Zillow.

â€œBut the effects of a government default associated with the impending debt-ceiling deadline would be more pronounced because of its greater impact on domestic and international markets. This will rattle consumers and investors alike, slow down the overall economic recovery and further slow the housing recovery, which is already undergoing a moderation in the pace of home value gains due to rising mortgage rates,â€ he warns.

link.title: Government Shutdown Risks Hurting The Housing Recovery

"Times New Roman";">The Property Appraiser determines the value of your home as of January 1, 2013 using sales from the previous year.  So property valuations are always going to lag behind the actual entry.title: The Importance of Flood Insurance
entry.content:
Watch on your mobile device >>

When you buy a home, youâ€™ll be asked if you want to purchase flood insurance. Sometimes itâ€™s obvious a homeowner needs such coverage, but other times the need is less clear. But the widespread flooding here in Florida caused last June by Tropical Storm Debby, not to mention the damage caused last October in the Northeast by Hurricane Sandy, should be a wake-up call about the importance of flood insurance to protect your home and possessions.  Many of the affected homeowners lived in areas of low flood risk, and many did not carry flood insurance.  With our official hurricane season just around the corner, now is the perfect time to review your coverage.

So how do you know if coverage is needed? Here are tips from Jim Martin at the Welch Group (www.thewelchgroup.net) that can help you decide.

1. Find out if you are in a flood zone. Any insurance agent should be able to tell you, and you sometimes can find the information on the property appraiserâ€™s website.

2. Learn your zone. The category of flood zone determines your flood insurance rate.  Mortgage lenders will require you to carry flood insurance if you live in the A zone or V zone. The X zone is a preferred-risk flood zone. Lenders may not require flood insurance, but you still may choose to carry it.

3. Get a copy of an elevation certificate. If you are in an A or V zone, be sure to get a copy of an elevation certificate from the current homeowner or through your local zoning department. Also, a surveyor can accomplish this for you.

4. Low-risk zone insurance is affordable. If you live in the low-risk zones of B, C or X, the coverage can be as low as $129 a year to a maximum of $376 a year for the best-possible coverage. Tropical Storm Debby caused a lot of the damage in the low-risk areas, and many homeowners were out of luck because they had not purchased flood insurance. Because all flood insurance is underwritten by the federal government, coverage costs the same price, regardless of the carrier.

For more information on flood insurance, contact me or Jim Martin at (888) 855-2921.

Maria Hoffman  Tampa Home Group (813) 907-2555  mariahoffman@verizon.net

link.title: The Importance of Flood Insurance

entry.title: What Does Sinkhole Insurance Really Cover?
entry.content:
Watch on your mobile device >>

Between 2006 and 2010 the insurance industry paid out $3.6 billion in sinkhole claims in Florida alone.    In fact, the amount of money paid out in sinkhole claims rivals hurricane claims.  With the recent stories about sinkholes making national news, we thought it might be a good time to get this information out to you.

What is a sinkhole?

A sinkhole is a collapse of the ground caused by a variety of reasons.  They can form gradually or suddenly.  In Florida the porous ground makes the state more prone to sinkholes, so because of this, home policies include mandatory catastrophic ground collapse insurance.  In order to be considered catastrophic, four criteria must be met to get the claim paid:

â€¢ The collapse of the ground must be sudden,
â€¢ Damage must be visible to the naked eye,
â€¢ There must be damage to the structure and foundation,
â€¢ The governing body must condemn the property.


Most claims donâ€™t meet all four of the criteria, in particular, the condemnation. Another type of coverageâ€”non-catastrophicâ€”is an endorsement that covers you even if your property is not condemned. Only one carrier, Citizens Property and Casualty, offers the endorsement which requires an inspection process. Your insurance agent can advise you if you want to take advantage of this type of insurance. If you already have the endorsement in place and it is affordable, you are probably best off not changing carriers, as it may be difficult to obtain this type of coverage with another insurer. We can put you in touch with preferred agents who can help answer your questions.

Friends, the news is everywhere,  the real estate market is changing quickly, and that creates OPPORTUNITIES. If you are thinking of making a move, call us today, and let us help you achieve your goals. When we list your home, because of our extensive network of past clients and friends, we may already have a buyer for your home. Stay tuned to our next edition of Tampa Home Group TV for details on how we can help you navigate todayâ€™s market to sell your existing home and purchase the home you really want. 

Your team from Tampa Home Group is to assist you with your real estate needs and questions. Please contact us at (813) 907-2555 Info@TampaHomeGroup.com. Weâ€™re here to help.

entry.title: The Secrets of Buying a Home When Faced with Multiple Bidders
entry.content:
Watch on your mobile device >>


The real estate market in the Tampa area has dramatically shifted in 2012. Our home inventory is at an all-time low, and competition to buy homes has increased.   We are regularly seeing multiple offer situations in all price ranges from investment property up through luxury homes.  (provided the homes are priced aggressively)

This means that when we help you find a home that is a great value, there will likely be other buyers who are just as eager as you to buy that home.  In fact, last weekend, our team wrote three offers on three different homes, and all three homes had attracted multiple bids.

Itâ€™s OUR job to make sure YOU WIN and secure the home you want.
In this competitive market, you must be prepared. Here are four tips to keep in mind to help you before you even start home shopping:

1. Time is of the essence. You must make your home search a priority. It might mean leaving work a bit early or visiting a home over your lunch break. You need to act quickly; you canâ€™t always wait until the weekend to go see a home.

2. Make an offer quickly. Once we find that great value, the longer it takes us to get our offer over to the seller, the more potential buyers enter the picture.  We can use time to our advantage if we are more prepared than other buyers.    Here is our commitment to you:  BEFORE WE GO OUT LOOKING, we are going to take the time to make sure we understand your needs fully, you understand what is going on in the market, and you have all the information you need to make an informed wise decision with confidence.

3. Make your offer strong and make sure it is presented professionally. Together, we will write a clean and strong offer that the seller wants.  We are not just talking about the price you offer.  What most buyers donâ€™t realize is that often small details and/or the way an agent presents an offer can make the difference in getting one offer accepted over another.  Sometimes important documents, proof of funds, or preapprovals are missing.  Many poorly written, incompletely filled out offers are sent to our office each monthâ€¦and we wonder if these buyers realize that their agent has not done a thorough job.  Our team will make sure the paperwork is filled out properly, details are handled and nothing is missing.  Did you know that asking for closing costs weakens an offer?  Sometimes buyers need help with closing costs, and we find ourselves in a competing offer situation.  We have a solution, there is a simple way to get your closing costs covered without asking the seller.  Weâ€™ll show you.

4. Find a knowledgeable agent. Before you start to shop, you must find a good buyerâ€™s agent whoâ€™s knowledgeable about the market youâ€™re considering. You wouldnâ€™t think about climbing Mount Everest without a guide, and you wouldnâ€™t think of performing your own surgery. Today itâ€™s common for buyers to start online, shop for a home, and end up in all types of complicated situations with no one to turn to for help because no one is representing their interests.  In the end, many of these people end up in our office with horror stories that have cost them time and money.  Let us help you avoid the hassles and find a great value.

Buying a home in todayâ€™s market should be a great experience.

link.title: The Secrets of Buying a Home When Faced with Multiple Bidders

entry.title: Tampa Real Estate Update for September 2012
entry.content:
Watch on your mobile device >>

In September, the Federal Reserve announced its plan to buy $40 billion of government-backed mortgages each month indefinitely until the employment situation significantly improves.

So what does that mean for home buyers and sellers like you? 

It means an already great time to buy real estate is about to get even better. Just when you thought earlier this year that rates couldnâ€™t possibly go lower, the Fed is seeking to pressure mortgage interest rates lower to make homes more affordable and stimulate the U.S. economy.

Just look at what this might do to mortgage payments:

â€¢ A $500,000, 30-year fixed mortgage that qualifies for â€œjumbo pricingâ€ â€“ loans with slightly higher mortgage rates because they are larger than the limits set by the federal  government  â€“  would mean a monthly principal-and-interest payment of just $2,245. And with no prepayment penalty.
â€¢ On a $300,000 mortgage, that monthly payment will be just $1,330 a month with the same terms.

What a great time this should be to buy investment properties and get a greater rate of return. It also should make it easier to upsize, downsize, or even to keep your home as an investment property, buy a new home, and lock into these rock-bottom low rates for the next 30 years.

Eventually, these interest rates will rise. Our best guess is that we will see 6-7 percent rates three to five years from now.

To take advantage of this unique opportunity, please call us at the Tampa Home Group office, and weâ€™ll give you the right answers for you and your specific situation.

entry.title: Access Your Tax Values Early and Understand How They Work
entry.content:
Watch on your mobile device >>


DID YOU KNOW YOU CAN GET A SNEAK PEEK AT YOUR 2012 PROPERTY TAX ASSESSMENT ONLINE? â€¦ Each year the property appraisers mail out the new 2012 valuations, but not everyone knows that they update their websites too â€“ if you want to check your homeâ€™s assessment, read on for the links you need.

TRIM NOTICES GO OUT THIS MONTH
Property Appraisers in each Florida county mail out new property valuations, called TRIM (Truth in Millage) notices to homeowners in August. This is NOT your actual tax bill â€“ that comes out in a few months.

HOW ARE VALUES CALCULATED?
The Property Appraiser determines the value of your home as of January 1, 2012 using sales from the previous year. So property valuations are always going to lag behind the actual market. As you might expect, distressed sales have had an impact on values in the past few years. Keep in mind that the amount your home is assessed for is not equivalent to what the home would sell for in today's market. If you need to know what your house would actually sell for â€“ please call us directly and we can help you. On your property record you will see two figures: Just Market Value and Assessed Value. Most Just Market Values on the TRIM notices have come down in 2012 as they did in 2009-2011. We have seen a few come up. 

ASSESSMENT MAY GO UP DESPITE MARKET VALUE...
While the 2012 values we have seen have been low, it is possible that your assessed value has risen.  Yes, this is possible.  Back in January 1993 the Save Our Homes Act capped increases on assessed value on homesteaded property at 3% per year OR the increase in the consumer price index, whichever was the lesser of the two. In the years when home values grew 10% or more, the increase on assessed value was capped at 3%. Now you may see the assessments play "catch up", recapturing the value by the allowed 3% increase.

2012 VALUATIONS NOW ONLINE
If you have not received your TRIM notice yet, most of the preliminary 2012 valuations are online now. Simply search your address on the county website, plus you'll find a wealth of additional resources:

Hillsborough County Property Appraiser website
Pasco County Property Appraiser website
Pinellas County Property Appraiser website

If you feel your assessment is unfairly high or a mistake has been made, you have the statutory right to appeal it. Keep in mind that you only have a short time to do so, so don't wait. Here are some helpful links:

How do I appeal my Hillsborough County tax assessment?
Pasco County Real Property Value Appeal Form
What is the procedure for appealing Pasco County property taxes?

HOW CAN I FIND OUT ABOUT THE SALE PRICES IN MY NEIGHBORHOOD?

If you'd like to know more about the sales around your home, take advantage of our FREE Market Snapshot reportsâ€¦ Click here for a custom report on actual sold prices around YOUR home! You'll receive a real-time report taken right out of the MLS. These are actual sold prices, much more accurate and timely than any other resource we've found. That includes Zillow â€“ if you didn't check it out, Zillow admits their info in Florida is terrible. This is Zillow's own data comparing their â€œZestimatesâ€ to actual sold data. You might be shocked to discover the median error percentages county by county.

OPPORTUNITIES IN REAL ESTATE TODAY
As always, we are here to help you reach your goals. The opportunities in real estate are unprecedented â€“ with low interest rates and prices, your dream home may be well within reach. Our team of real estate professionals has helped a record number of families move up, relocate to Tampa or purchase investment property in 2012. We thank you for referring your friends and family to us.

link.title: Access Your Tax Values Early and Understand How They Work

entry.title: Shifting Luxury Home Market Provides Great Selling Opportunity
entry.content:
Watch on your mobile device >>

In 2009, at the height of the housing crisis, almost half of sales closed were bank owned or short sales.  In some price ranges and neighborhoods, distressed sales were as much as 80% of the market.   These distressed properties dictated the Tampa-area real estate market, and, as a result, many traditional sellers could not sell their homes. They simply couldnâ€™t compete with the rock-bottom prices for bank-owned and short sale homes.

Three years later, the market has shifted in dramatic fashion. We study the numbers constantly, and wanted to share this striking trend with you.  We looked at Tampa zip code 33647, and we see these numbers mirrored in other zip codes across the market, this year, 90 percent of homes sold over $300,000 are traditional salesâ€”non bank-owned, non short sale. 

In other words, the distressed sales no longer dominate the market, and appraisers now are able to pull sales numbers from regular traditional sales.  Short sales and bank owned properties will still be with us for the next 3-4 years, and still will prevent dramatic price gains.

What does this mean if youâ€™re looking to buy? The Tampa home market has hit bottom, and itâ€™s a fabulous opportunity to buy, especially with mortgage interest rates under 4 percent.

What does this mean if you want to sell? You might think you can just hold on to a property for a few years and wait to sell. But that strategy is complicated by the fact that the rise in home prices will be very modest â€“ growth of perhaps 1 to 2 percent annually as bank-owned and short-sell homes still act as a drag.

Selling is a case-by-case situation, but if you want to sell a $400,000 home now, someone can buy it and pay $1,500-1,600 a month (principal and interest). When rates return to the 7-to-8-percent level, a home at that price will mean a mortgage payment of more than $2,500-2,700. There are many more potential buyers now than when interest rates inevitably rise.

If you want to upsize and take advantage of these low interest rates, you donâ€™t want to be someone a few years from now who says, â€œWow I wish I could have bought that house back in 2012, because now I canâ€™t afford toâ€¦â€

Short Sale Disadvantages

Short sale homes can still be found, even though their number has decreased dramatically.  When we study the number of active and pending short sales vs. the number that actually close, we see that less than half of short sales are actually closing.  Many short sale transactions have problems closing because of second mortgages, uncooperative sellers, and the unforeseen circumstances common with short salesâ€”and often buyers find this out only after months of waiting.

Plus, the federal law that allows the short-sale deficiency amount to be tax free (not treated as income by the IRS) expires at the end of 2012. Thereâ€™s no talk in Washington to extend this provision. So without an extension of this law, short-sellers can potentially face a significant tax burden after 2012. 

Looking to buy or sell in the Tampa-area market? Let us help you create a strategy tailored to your needs. Contact us today at 813-907-2555 or mariahoffman@verizon.net, and we will help you make that dream home a reality.

link.title: Shifting Luxury Home Market Provides Great Selling Opportunity

entry.title: Buy your Dream Luxury Home at a Rock-Bottom Price
entry.content:
Watch on your mobile device >>

A Tampa-area luxury home has never been more affordable. Thatâ€™s because there are still great deals on luxury bank-owned properties throughout Hillsborough, Pasco County and Pinellas.

An Inside Look at the Luxury Distressed Home Market

A Tampa-area luxury home has never been more affordable.   For example, this luxury home Iâ€™m standing in at this writing is in excellent condition was listed at $1.3 million in 2007, and in todayâ€™s market it will sell in the $500â€™S.   This home received multiple offers when it came on the market a few weeks ago.  This is just one fantastic home-buying opportunity.   But to get in on these types of incredible home deals, you need to be prepared.  At the bottom Iâ€™ll give you the link to a waterfront bank owned property we just put on the market Saturday.

Did You Know?

In a market known for an abundance of distressed property, it might surprise you to know that the luxury market has quite a different footprint from the rest of the Tampa Bay home market, with distressed property making up only a tiny percentage of the active listings.

In Hillsborough County, there are currently 624 single family homes priced at $500,000 and up on the market.  Only 1% are bank-owned.  Only 5% are short sales.

While the majority of our clients are traditional home sellers and homebuyers like you, part of our business today involves listing distressed luxury homes for banks.  Our office phones start ringing once our For Sale sign goes up in a sought after neighborhood.   But by the time the sign goes up, buyers need to be ready, because these homes often receive multiple offers and go under contract quickly.

Friends, what we are sharing with you is not unique to bank owned propertyâ€¦. the entire LUXURY HOME MARKET is on sale.  So whether you are thinking of purchasing a bank-owned home, a short sale, new construction, or resale luxury home, do you have your strategy in place?

Â·Do you need to sell your current home in order to qualify to purchase a new one?

Â·Should you keep your current home as rental property and purchase the next? (This strategy makes financial sense for some.)

Â·Have you spoken with a reputable lender about the requirements of purchasing, and do have an up to date pre-approval?

These are all questions you need to answer before that FOR SALE sign goes up in front of your dream home.

A common scenario we encounter is getting a call from an excited buyer who has been watching a home, perhaps for months or years, with possible plans to buy it.   The reality is that in the case of bank-owned property, or short sales for that matter, banks will not even consider contingent offers. And savvy home sellers wonâ€™t either.  So if you have a home to sell,  and youâ€™d like to be one of the fortunate buyers who secure one of todayâ€™s great values, NOW is the time to sit down and come up with a strategy.  You may be in a situation where it makes financial sense to keep your existing home as a rental and purchase the new property.  We can help you with that conversation, and connect you with the proper mortgage professionals who can educate you on the best mortgage options for your situation.

If you are ready to create a home-buying strategy that lets you grab a great home as soon as it comes on the market, contact us today at 813-907-2555 or mariahoffman@verizon.net and we will help you make that dream home a reality.

P.S. In the midst of getting ready to send this out to you, we just put another waterfront home in Sweetwater active on Saturday June 30â€”check it out here, and contact us right away if you have interest in this home.  02-Res Customer Synopsis

entry.title: Tampa Bay Area Summer Real Estate Market Report
entry.content:
Watch on your mobile device >>

Inventory Levels At Their Lowest In Years


In the past few months, we have experienced a lot of positive activity in our marketplace. In fact, our inventory has diminished so quickly that the general public is simply not aware of what is taking place in our Tampa Bay market, or why.   After years of 20, 25, or even 30 months of inventory in many price ranges, we are now experiencing a shortage of quality listings.  While 6 months of inventory is considered a normal market, would you believe that we are now in a market with only 3.7 months of inventoryâ€”even less in some price ranges!

This creates an opportunity for sellers, one we have not seen for years.

Multiple factors are at work

Interest rates are at their all-time historic lows.

Banks have money to lend, and are lending.

Low prices have created more buyers in every price range.  Affordability has sellers excited to take advantage of what they can purchase once they do sell their homes.  Even if they sell for less, they are able to purchase for less at record low rates.

Before a national election, people tend to be more optimistic about the economy.

Buyers are out in record numbers, scrambling to take advantage of the low rates and low prices.

Bank owned inventory had decreased.  Short sale inventory has decreased.

Jumbo rates have also hit historic lows, creating more buyers in the luxury market.

Take a look at the inventory levels in your price range:




Sellers Receiving Top Dollar for Their Homes


Another exciting phenomenon for sellers today is the number of multiple offers coming in on homes in great condition that are priced well.  With inventory down more than 50% over the previous yearâ€™s numbers, sellers can finally see light at the end of the tunnel. We are seeing multiple offers that in many cases end up in bidding wars â€“ ending up in very happy sellers.   With 7,770 available open listings on the market in our region this could not be a better time for our sellers. We are seeing many homes selling in less than 30 days after listing the property and even faster if your property is priced right, located in a great location and is in great condition.  Remember that in order to get top dollar, your home will need to be in top dollar condition.  Part of the service we provide to you when you list your home with us is the guidance to get your home in top selling condition.



How Long Will Current Market Conditions Last?


There is no way to tell how long this current cycle of real estate activity will continue. For the next few months, we can expect to see more of what we are experiencing today. But after that, with the election, potential unloading of shadow inventory and possible increase in mortgage rates â€“ the next cycle is anyoneâ€™s guess.

Remember, this is a great time to be a seller in the Tampa Bay area, and we want to help you evaluate your options if selling might be in your near future. So if you have been on the fence, unsure of whether this is the right time to sell â€“ itâ€™s time to jump off the fence! Give us a call today so we can work with you to determine what the highest paying retail buyers will pay for your home.

entry.title: Your Real Estate Check-Up â€“ Understanding Todayâ€™s Goals, Achieving Them Tomorrow
entry.content:
Watch on your mobile device >>

As your family Realtors, our success is based upon your successâ€¦ whether that means saving you money on the purchase of a home, earning you more on the sale of your existing home, helping you purchase vacation, retirement, or investment property, or simply helping you identify and then realize your goals. We often find many of our friends and clients have a general idea of their real estate goals, but do not have a clearly defined plan of action, or are so busy they fail to take action.  Do you have clear goals?  Are they realistic?    Fast forward five years or even tenâ€¦where do you want to be living?   Will investment property be part of your portfolio?  Are you basing your expectations on actual market data, or just the national headlines?  Are there any major home improvements you are considering and do you know how they will affect the saleability of your home?   Are there opportunities in the market you might be missing?

To help guide our friends and clients â€“ we have developed a â€œReal Estate Check Upâ€ that enables us to pinpoint ways for you to save money, keep you and your family safe, maintain or improve your homeâ€™s value, while defining and taking action toward your long term real estate goals.  Whether you are a homeowner, a homebuyer or homeseller, we will address your needs.

Knowledge is Power

We are committed is to know and understand our clients. The Real Estate Check Up is a set of questions weâ€™ve developed with your needs in mind.. it is based on situations we encounter in working with our clients on a daily basis.

Working Toward Excellent Returns

Through our Real Estate Check Up, we have the opportunity to outline exactly what it is that our clients desire and then come up with a specific action plan.  For example, if you are thinking of selling in the future, we can discuss which home improvement projects will result in the best returns for  resale.  If you are in the market to buy a home in the near or distant future, we can help educate you and put you in a position of strength before you enter the market. Weâ€™ll cover areas like:

- Refinancing
- Steps you can take to get the best mortgage rates, and which programs make the most sense for you
- Getting the best rates on homeowners insurance
- Renting out vs. selling your home
- Common safety precautions all homeowners should take

Seizing Todayâ€™s Opportunities for Tomorrowâ€™s Peace of Mind

Without a doubt, the current real estate market reflects an unprecedented buying environment that might never again be seen. With interest rates at record-setting lows and housing prices to match, we know that to buy now will enable to look back and be glad you seized the opportunity. Rather than see our friends miss out on this amazing chance to get ahead now and in the future â€“ we want to share all the exciting things that our marketplace has to offer right now. We pledge to show you how you can save money and make more money in the long run, while enjoying the home of your dreams in the process. No matter what you see yourself doing, having the solid backing of sound real estate decisions will be the cornerstone of a strong future.

We would like to be the ones that share valuable insight into your real estate goals so that rather than looking back someday thinking â€œI wish I knew back then what I know nowâ€ you can confidently be assured that you have made the best decisions possible. We invite you today to call us at 813-907-2555 or email us today at mariahoffman@verizon.net and request your copy of the Real Estate Check Up, so we can get you one step closer to your goals!
